Who are getting infected by the Delta variant, and who are the carriers? Interestingly, while the wild-type infectio gain insights, we simulate a dangerous hypothetical variant, which we refer to as "Neos." Neos is designed to be deadlier by increasing its (i) infectivity (14% higher than the Delta variant), (ii) vaccine escape rate (70% for one dose of Pfizer or AstraZeneca, similar to Delta which is 67%; 25% and 50% for two doses of Pfizer and AstraZeneca, respectively; compared to 12% and 40% for Delta), and (iii) fraction of asymptomatic infections (55% instead of 50%). Recovery rate, mortality rate, and other clinical features are assumed to be the same as the wild type. We assume that Neos emerges in the fall of 2021. The predicted population dynamics that describe its spread, from August 1 2021 to June 30 2022, is shown in Fig. 9. After its introduction, Neos quickly takes hold due to its high transmissivity, and by the end of 2021, it has overtaken Delta to account for the majority of new infections (Fig. 9c). By mid 2022, the infected individuals would account for 1% of the entire population (Fig. 9f), despite nearly 80% of the population having been vaccinated. all_text: Figure 11. Predicted spread of hypothetical VOC "Neos," shown from August 1 2021 to June 31 2022. Results are obtained for three scenarios: (a1) more stringent NPI, with mobility decreased further by 40% starting September 1 2021; (b1) a third vaccine booster that offers twice the protection of health conditions. Furthermore, spatial heterogeneity likely has a significant impact on the spread of infections. As can be seen in the geographical heterogeneity in the number of COVID-19 cases in Ontario, socio-economic factors also play an important role in the local spread of COVID-19. These factors include the number of people per household, job locations, frequency of public transportation usage, regional vaccination rates, and social connectedness, etc. Different socio-economic groups are likely affected differently by the NPI. Thus, a worthwhile extension would be to divide Ontario into regions with distinct demographics, represent the spread of COVID-19 within each region using an incarnation of the SV2(AIR)3 model, and then loosely connect these sub-models based on the estimated amounts of communications mediated by job or social travels. The present model is formulated using data from Ontario, Canada (Ontario COVID-19 Science Advisory Table). Geographical and socio-economic parameters can be refitted to simulate VOC dynamics in a different province in Canada or a different country (e.g., infectivity β, vaccine type ε, COVID-19 mortality rate μX, NPI λ). These models can be a valuable decision-support tool for public health. Scientific Reports | (2022) 12:2114 | https://doi.org/10.1038/s41598-022-06159-x 13 Vol.:(0123456789)www.nature.com/scientifi

The text describes a computational model for simulating the spread of three SARS-CoV-2 strains (wild type, Alpha, and Delta) in Ontario. The population in the province is divided into several classes based on their health and vaccination status. The model tracks two "susceptible" populations: the original susceptible population (S) and the population that has lost immunity from either vaccination or infection (SVR). The original susceptible population (S) vaccinates at a rate of ω1 and enters the V1 vaccine types, which are represented by Pfizer-BioNTech (M = PZ) and AstraZeneca (M = AZ). The fractions of Pfizer-BZ and AstraZeneca vaccines are denoted by εPZ and εAZ, respectively, with εPZ representing Pfizer and Moderna vaccines. The total population in Ontario is not explicitly stated, but it can be inferred that it is the total population being simulated. The text also mentions that those who received the first dose will receive their second dose, but no rate for this is given.

The meltwater outflow is idealized as a prescribed, constant buoyancy source applied to the bottom of the model domain. The real-world buoyancy source is a function of complex melting and mixing processes beneath the ice shelf, but for the purposes of this study, the focus is on treating it as a tunable parameter. all_text: in the spirit of Morton et al. (1956). Here, the rate of turbulent entrainment of ambient fluid into the rising buoyant plume is parameterized as proportional to the plume's vertical velocity via an entrainment coefficient a. We assume that the vertical velocity w is uniform within the plume and zero outside, and that the plume is rising next to a wall (so that entrainment can only occur from one side). We can then write down volume, momentum, and mass conservation equations within the plume: d dz (Dw) 5 aw, d dz (Dwrw) 5 Dg(r 2 r), a d dz (Dwr) 5 awr a. (A1) (A2) (A3) Here, r(z) is the density of the plume, ra(z) is the ambient density, D is the width of the plume perpendicular to the wall, and a is the entrainment coefficient. Assuming that r(z) differs only slightly from the reference density r0, we can rewrite Eq. (A2) as We implement the buoyancy source F (m4 s 23) in our highresolution simulations as a volume-conserving ''virtual salinity flux'' (Huang 1993). The conservation law for an arbitrary tracer c in Oceananigans.jl is ›c ›t 1 u (cid:2) =c 5 2= (cid:2) qc 1 Fc, (B1) where qc is a diffusive flux and Fc is an external source term. In our simulations, we introduce the buoyancy uniformly across a volume that extends width L in the x direction, 10 grid cells in the y direction (;100 m), and one grid cell in the z direction (;4 m). The width of 100 m in the y direction is chosen in part to simulate the fact that the plume has nonzero horizontal momentum when emerging from beneath the ice shelf, while still remaining consistent with observations and prior simulation

The experiment is conducted twice, once with a realistic rotation (l = 1/20 s) and once with f = 0 24 s. In the buoyancy source region, the temperature changes at a rate given by equation (C1). Melting is spatially distributed throughout the ice-shelf cavity, and the meltwater that is released loses buoyancy as it ascends toward the ice-shelf front. If the meltwater plume carries a buoyancy flux F by the time it reaches the base of the ice shelf, the smallest possible rate of mass loss that could be responsible for that buoyancy flux would be achieved if all of the meltwater that enters the ice shelf at the base is buoyant and rises to the surface. This is an approximation, as some of the meltwater may mix with the surrounding water and lose buoyancy before reaching the surface.

Therefore, the smallest possible rate of mass loss that could be responsible for a given buoyancy flux F is given by:

mass loss rate = F / (density difference between meltwater and surrounding water)

where density difference is the difference between the density of meltwater and the density of the surrounding water. The density of meltwater is assumed to be constant at 1025 kg/m^3, and the density of the surrounding water is given by the equation of state for seawater:

density = 1000 + αT

where α is the thermal expansion coefficient of seawater, and T is the temperature in degrees Celsius.

Therefore, the smallest possible rate of mass loss that could be responsible for a given buoyancy flux F is:

mass loss rate = F / (1025 - (1000 + αT))

where F is the buoyancy flux, α is the thermal expansion coefficient of seawater, and T is the temperature in degrees Celsius at the base of the ice shelf.

This equation can be used to calculate the smallest possible rate of mass loss for a given buoyancy flux and temperature. For example, if the buoyancy flux is 10^6 kg/m^2/s and the temperature at the base of the ice shelf is 0 degrees Celsius, the smallest possible rate of mass loss would be:

mass loss rate = 10^6 / (1025 - (1000 + α * 0)) = 10^6 / 1255 = 8.03 x 10^4 kg/m^2/s

This equation assumes that all of the meltwater that enters the ice shelf at the base is buoyant and rises to the surface, which is an approximation. In reality, some of the meltwater may mix with the surrounding water and lose buoyancy before reaching the surface, resulting in a larger actual rate of mass loss.

all_text: Modelling the COVID-19 epidemic and implementation of population-wide interventions in Italy Giulia Giordano Angela Di Matteo3 and Marta Colaneri3 1 ✉, Franco Blanchini2, Raffaele Bruno3,4, Patrizio Colaneri5,6, Alessandro Di Filippo3, In Italy, 128,948 confirmed cases and 15,887 deaths of people who tested positive for SARS-CoV-2 were registered as of 5 April 2020. Ending the global SARS-CoV-2 pandemic requires implementation of multiple population-wide strategies, including social distancing, testing and contact tracing. We propose a new model that predicts the course of the epidemic to help plan an effective control strategy. The model considers eight stages of infection: susceptible (S), infected (I), diagnosed (D), ailing (A), recognized (R), threatened (T), healed (H) and extinct (E), collectively termed SIDARTHE. Our SIDARTHE model discriminates between infected individuals depending on whether they have been diagnosed and on the severity of their symptoms. The distinction between important diagnosed and non-

We believe these indications can be useful to manage the epidemic in Italy, as well as in countries that are still in the early stages of outbreak. Although the mortality rate (number of deaths in the whole population) of COVID-19 can be decreased with restrictive measures that reduce the spread of SARS-CoV-2, the CFR (number of deaths in the infected population) is essentially constant in different scenarios, unaffected by the extent of social restriction and testing. Susceptible population, infected population, dead population, asymptomatic population, recovered population, hospitalized population, and exposed population are variables in a mathematical model for the spread of a disease. The variables sum to 1, meaning that the total population is represented by the sum of these variables. The variables S, I, D, A, and R represent the fractions of the population in each of these categories, while T, H, and E represent the actual number of individuals in each category. The variables are initialized to 0, except for S, which is initialized to a value greater than 0.

The text describes an equilibrium state of the model, where the variables converge to certain values. The values for S, I, D, A, and R are all 0, indicating that there are no susceptible, infected, dead, or asymptomatic individuals in the population. The value for R is 1/6, which represents the fraction of the population that has recovered. The values for T, H, and E are not specified in the text.

The text describes a mathematical model for the spread of a disease, specifically COVID-19, in a population. The model uses a system of differential equations to describe the dynamics of the different compartments of the population: susceptible (S), exposed (E), infectious but undiagnosed (I), infectious and diagnosed (D), asymptomatic infected (A), hospitalized (H), and recovered or deceased (R) and (T). The text also provides the initial conditions for these compartments and the values of the parameters that describe the transmission, recovery, death, and transition rates between the different compartments. The text also calculates the basic reproduction number (R0) for the model, which is a measure of the average number of new infections generated by a single infected individual in a population where everyone is susceptible. The text also describes how the parameters change over time due to various interventions, such as social distancing and lockdowns, and how these changes affect the basic reproduction number.

* I: population fraction of undiagnosed infected individuals, 200/60e6

The text describes a mathematical model for the spread of an infectious disease, COVID-19, and how different parameters affect the basic reproduction number (R0) and the peak of the epidemic. The text mentions several scenarios with different values of the parameters α, β, γ, δ, and ε, but no numerical values are given for these parameters. The text also mentions the basic reproduction number (R0) and how it relates to the peak of the epidemic.

Based on the context of the text, we can infer that:

α | infection rate | The rate at which susceptible individuals become infected.
β | transmission rate | The rate at which infected individuals transmit the disease to other susceptible individuals.
γ | recovery rate | The rate at which infected individuals recover and become immune to the disease.
δ | death rate | The rate at which infected individuals die from the disease.
ε | fraction of population susceptible to infection | The proportion of the population that is still susceptible to the disease.
R0 | basic reproduction number | The average number of secondary cases generated by a single primary case in a population where everyone is susceptible to the disease.

The text describes how different values of these parameters affect the basic reproduction number (R0) and the peak of the epidemic. For example, if ε is decreased (i.e., fewer individuals are susceptible to the disease), then R0 is also decreased, which can delay or reduce the peak of the epidemic. Similarly, if social-distancing measures are implemented, which reduce the infection and transmission rates (α and β), then R0 is also reduced, which can anticipate or reduce the peak of the epidemic. Conversely, if social-distancing measures are not implemented or are only mildly effective, then R0 remains larger than 1, which can lead to a delayed and larger peak of the epidemic.

This text is a recipe for making a simple syrup, which is a sweetener used in cocktails.

**Simple Syrup Recipe**

**Ingredients:**

* 1 cup [water]
* 2 cups [sugar]

**Instructions:**

1. Combine [water] and [sugar] in a medium saucepan.
2. Heat over medium heat, stirring occasionally, until [sugar] is completely dissolved.
3. Remove from heat and let cool to room temperature.
4. Strain the syrup through a fine-mesh sieve into a clean container.
5. Store in the refrigerator for up to 1 month.
